awd_titl_txt: Impacts of the Biosphere on Global Tropospheric Chemistry and Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on improving the representation of biosphere-atmosphere exchange processes in atmospheric chemical transport models. The overall objectives of the project are to investigate the impact of future land-use change on surface-atmosphere exchange processes, and to improve the characterization of the pre-industrial atmospheric composition. The project will aid in the development of sound policies for promoting air quality and a sustainable environment.

This research is directed toward evaluating and improving GEOS-Chem global model simulations of dry deposition, organic aerosol aging, and bioaerosols.  The focus of this work is on short-lived climate forcers: ozone and aerosols. The GEOS-Chem model is being used to isolate the impact of land surface modifications on chemical fluxes and atmospheric composition.  Modeling results will be evaluated using ambient field observations from surface sites and airborne campaigns over the last decade.

por.por_cntn:
Gases and particles in the atmosphere affect air quality, the radiative balance of the planet, and ecosystem health. The goal of this project was to better understanding interactions between the biosphere and atmosphere that control atmospheric composition.

First, we explored how vegetation removes ozone, a component of surface smog, from the atmosphere. We first used observations to test how current modeling schemes represent this process and then explored how machine learning techniques can be used to improve upon these modeling descriptions. Second, we investigated the drivers of bioaerosol emissions, in particular fungal spores, and how these aerosols can be described in global models. Third, we used observations and models to better understand the sources and trends in organic aerosol in the atmosphere. Our work showed that substantial progress has been made over the last decade in our ability to simulate the amount and variability of organic aerosol in the atmosphere. We also identified that the downward trend in organic aerosol over the United States since 1990 has largely been driven by a decrease in anthropogenic emissions. Finally, we used modeling tools to investigate how human-driven land use change since the year 1850 has modified the short-lived constituents in the atmosphere. The primary drivers for change from 1850 to present-day were decreasing organic emissions from natural vegetation due to global deforestation, and the increase in ammonia emissions associated with the growth in agriculture.

This project supported in whole or in part the work of two graduate students and three postdoctoral researchers, and the publication of 10 peer-reviewed manuscripts as well as numerous conference presentations. The research was coupled to the development of a graduate class at MIT. The research group also contributed to a student-led initiative to provide media resources to explain environmental science concepts to the public at large by developing two videos on air quality.
